page.title: Review and Session 3 Objectives
page.contents:
Explicit Instruction Lesson Plan – Skill/Strategy Learning

Last session we:

  • Described the importance of developing students’ ability to be self-regulated learners.
  • Described the components of a Lesson Introduction that incorporates principles of explicit instruction.
  • Prepared you to develop a Lesson Introduction relevant to your learners using an explicit instruction lesson plan format.


In this session we will:

  • Describe skills and strategies in the context of EI and self-regulated learning.
  • Describe how to task analyze an academic skill or strategy into steps.
  • Describe how to explain and model a strategy or skill (including the use of a ‘think aloud’).
  • Continue development of an EI Lesson incorporating the ‘explain and model’ steps for a skill or strategy (based on a task analysis).

EI Lesson Plan Format:

As previously stated, we are working our way through the four parts of our explicit instruction lesson plan format. In this session we will focus on the second part:

  1. Lesson Introduction
  2. Teacher Explanation and Demonstration/Modeling <<<<
  3. Practice
  4. Closure


Click on the Next button below to continue.

page.title: Self-Regulation and EI: Explanation and Modeling
page.contents:
From the previous session you may remember that our goal as adult education instructors is to teach in a way that helps our students become independent or self-regulated learners.

Explicit instruction is designed to help students master basic skills as well as higher order thinking strategies that are the building blocks for success in any academic or vocational area. In explicit instruction we support this mastery through task analysis.

A task analysis breaks down what we are teaching in a series of steps. The teacher then explains and models these steps, which the learners then use to practice new skills and/or content.

When modeling, it is important that instructors think aloud as well. When teachers model and explain their own thought processes, learners are more likely to understand and begin to use those same processes on their own.  This is an essential part of EI. Modeling new skills and/or concepts - based on a task analysis - combined with the use of “think alouds,” supports the development of self-regulation in adult learners.

What is a task analysis? Have you ever based your instruction on one? If so, how did you conduct the task analysis?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Teacher Explanation is based in a Task Analysis
page.contents:
An important part of an explicit instruction lesson is making sure that we have a clear set of steps that students will learn to follow. The process we use to develop these steps is called a task analysis.

Task Analysis is the process of breaking down an academic task into steps that teachers can explain and demonstrate.

A task analysis provides the basis for the teacher explanation, as well as the demonstration/modeling parts of the EI lesson.

Let’s take a closer look at the task analysis process.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis
page.contents:
How we teach can have either a negative or positive effect on developing students into self-regulated learners.  Explicit Instruction is designed to enable to students to develop this important learning attribute.

Here are the steps to doing a task analysis.

  1. Identify a critical basic skill or higher order thinking strategy learners need to be able to perform.
  2. Divide it into steps.
  3. Determine prerequisite knowledge and skills needed to perform the steps.
  4. Develop methods to assess students’ prerequisite knowledge and skills.

Does this process sound familiar?
Have you used it in your work with adult learners?

 

Task analysis is important in teaching basic skills, such as how to multiply or write a simple sentence. Task analysis is also important in teaching higher order thinking strategies, such as how to solve math word problems or to write a persuasive essay.

Let’s work through two task analyses:

  > One task analysis will be for a basic skill: How to add decimals.

  >  The other task analysis will be for a higher order thinking strategy:
      How to answer literal and inferential reading comprehension questions.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis of a Basic Skill – Steps 1 & 2
page.contents:
A basic skill is a procedure that with practice can be performed automatically. Basic skills require very little or no higher order thinking.

Task Analysis Step 1:  Identify a basic skill or higher order thinking strategy learners need to be able to perform.

Let’s begin with the basic skill of adding decimals, as in the following sample problem:    

Add 1.452 to 1.3

Task Analysis Step 2:  Divide the task into steps.

But wait, what are the ‘right’ steps?

 Take a minute and solve the problem below, and list the steps you followed.    

1.452 + 1.3 = _________

When you are done, click on the Next button to compare your steps to the steps on the next slide.

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis of a Basic Skill – Steps 2 & 3
page.contents:
Here is one way to break this task down into steps.*

Task Analysis Step 2:  Divide the task into steps.

1.452 + 1.3 = _________

  1. Write down the numbers, one under the other, with the decimal points lined up.
  2. Put in zeros (“pad” the zeros) so the numbers have the same length.
  3. Then add normally, remembering to put the decimal point in the answer.

* Source: MathIsFun.com

How did your steps compare? Did you have more steps, or fewer? Is yours also a “right” way to break down this task?

 

Now that we have broken down our task, let’s look at our next step.

Task Analysis Step 3: Determine prerequisite knowledge and skills.

A task analysis builds on knowledge and skills that the student has acquired previously. These prerequisites must be clearly identified.

What prerequisite knowledge and skills does a learner need to know before learning to add decimals? Take a minute and list the prerequisites for our example problem.

When you are done, click on the Next button to compare your steps to the steps on the next slide.

 Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis of a Basic Skill – Steps 3 & 4
page.contents:
Task Analysis Step 3: Determine prerequisite knowledge and skills.

We think that some important prerequisite knowledge and skills for adding decimals are:

  • Skill in basic addition facts
  • Skill in adding multidigit numbers with regrouping
  • Knowledge of decimals

 

 

How did your list of prerequisite skills compare?

 

You may have thought of other prerequisites, or stated them somewhat differently, but let’s use this list for now and move on to Step 4.

Task Analysis Step 4: Develop methods to assess students’ prerequisite knowledge and skills.

After you identify the prerequisite skills, develop a short assessment to determine if learners have these prerequisites.

Take a minute and think about how you might quickly assess each of the prerequisites for adding decimals with your learners.  What ‘sample items’ might you put on a short quiz, for example?

When you are done, click on the Next button to compare your steps to the steps on the next slide.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis of a Basic Skill – Step 4 Activity Possible Responses
page.contents:
Task Analysis Step 4: Develop methods to assess students’ prerequisite knowledge and skills.

Below are some sample items to address each of our listed prerequisites for adding decimals:

To assess skill in basic addition facts

Add the following numbers (common addition facts):

3 + 4 = ____     7 + 4 = ____     6 + 3 = ____      7 + 8 = ____     9 + 9 = ____ 

 

To assess skill in adding multidigit numbers with regrouping

Add the following numbers:

12 + 59 = ____    33 + 8 + 13 = ____   

 

To assess knowledge of decimals

Which is more? (Circle your answer)

1.5 or 1.456     46.999 or 78.4     13.003 or 13.02     7.6 or 7 ½    27.3 or 27 ¼ 

How did your approach (or items) for assessing prerequisites skills compare? What would you do if a student did not have the prerequisite skills?

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Supporting students who lack pre-requisite skills
page.contents:
Task Analysis Step 4: Develop methods to assess students’ prerequisite knowledge and skills.

Note that this step in the task analysis connects with the Lesson Introduction component: Review and check for prerequisite skills.

The task analysis process assists you to identify the needed skills and to design a check for those skills that you would use as a part of your lesson introduction. In addition, during the task analysis, instructors should consider how they will modify instruction for students who do not have the prerequisite skills.

In the example we are using this may mean:

  • practicing addition facts,
  • practicing addition with regrouping, and/or
  • reviewing decimals.

 

What other supports might you plan for students who lack the prerequisite skills for adding decimals?

 

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis – higher order thinking strategies
page.contents:
So far we have examined an example of a task analysis for a basic math skill. Let’s move on to higher order thinking (HOT) strategies.

First of all, we need to define what we mean by “strategy” in this context.

A strategy is a procedure a learner uses to perform a complex task. Strategies are comprised of thinking and action steps to help learners develop higher order thinking skills.

A number of research-based strategies have been developed and tested for effectiveness. In general, teachers should try to use these tested strategies rather than developing their own. Let’s take a look at one example.

Examine two sets of reading comprehension strategies found in Learning to Achieve: A Professional’s Guide to Educating Adults with Learning Disabilities.See Figure 11 and 12 on Reading Comprehension Strategies on Page 76. 


Note that each strategy is presented as a series of steps to follow, but that how these steps are presented varies. Sometimes…

  • the first letter of the step is mnemonic – ASK IT (Figure 11),
  • the steps are numbered (Figure 12), or
  • the steps are unnumbered (Figure 11).

Let’s try the task analysis process for a higher order thinking strategy.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis of a HOT Strategy – Step 1
page.contents:
Task Analysis Step 1:  Identify a basic skill or higher order thinking strategy learners need to be able to perform.

The higher order thinking skill we are going to address is the ability to answer both literal and inferential reading comprehension  questions. 

A literal comprehension question asks the student to recall or find information that is clearly stated in the text.

An inferential comprehension question requires the student to draw on their own knowledge, as well as pull information from the text, in order to understand the reading.

Given a reading passage and several comprehension questions, both literal and inferential, we want this learner to be able to:

  • distinguish the types of questions and,
  • based on their reading, provide answers to the questions.

How would you approach teaching this skill?
What would you envision as the “steps” to this higher order thinking process?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis of a HOT Strategy – Step 2
page.contents:
Task Analysis Step 2:  Divide the task into steps.

As we noted before, when teaching strategies, it is helpful to use already-developed strategies that have a research base. Thus this step is more about *finding* an existing researched step-by-step process than creating one yourself.

One such strategy that addresses our chosen reading comprehension skill is the Question – Answer Relationship Strategy (QAR).

QAR is a strategy that teaches learners how to answer reading comprehension questions. The strategy guides learners to categorize questions based on how information is presented in a reading passage. 

Learners start by identifying questions that can be answered by information that is easiest to find and then move through a passage to answer more inferential questions. The strategy is divided into three parts.

  1. Right There - Identify information that is in one place in the passage.
  2. Think and Search - Identify information that has to be put together from different parts of the passage.
  3. Writer and Me - Identify what you already know and how it helps you understand the reading.

(Raphael & Au, 2005)

Take a few moments to review the QAR strategy and to consider what prerequisite skills would be required for successful use of this strategy.

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis of a HOT Strategy – Step 3
page.contents:
Task Analysis Step 3: Determine prerequisite knowledge and skills.

Here is a list of the prerequisites that we feel are important for learners to be able to learn this strategy:

  • Passage reading level - Learners should be learning this strategy in passages on their comprehension reading levels.
  • Background knowledge - Learners should have some background knowledge of the passage topic.
  • Literal comprehension - Learners should be able to answer simple literal comprehension questions.

Again, the prerequisites you listed may differ, depending on your learners. For the next step, however, we’ll use this list above. 

Consider the methods a teacher might use to assess this list of prerequisite knowledge and skills for the QAR strategy. Note down your ideas.

When you are done, click on the next button to compare your steps to the steps on the next slide.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis of a HOT Strategy – Step 4
page.contents:
Task Analysis Step 4: Develop methods to assess students’ prerequisite knowledge and skills.

To conduct a prerequisite assessment for QAR the teacher might

  • ensure that the reading passages match the learners’ comprehension levels by
    • asking comprehension questions or
    • using a “cloze” test in which words are omitted at regular intervals and learners are asked to supply the missing words. (Ideas for using cloze tests are readily available in literacy texts or on the web).
  • assess background knowledge by asking questions on relevant topics and key vocabulary words.
  • test literal comprehension by asking simple comprehension questions.

The QAR strategy is just one of many research-based strategies that can help learners begin to guide their own reading comprehension. The three steps of QAR give learners a road map of types of questions that can help them comprehend a reading passage. The QAR steps are the basis for teacher explanation and modeling in this EI lesson.

How can providing a clear set of steps to follow help learners begin to gain the confidence and competence that supports self-regulated learning?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Task Analysis and self-regulated learners
page.contents:
While a good task analysis is useful throughout the explicit instruction process, the steps of the task analysis play a particularly important role in the Explain and Model part of an explicit instruction lesson.

During the Explanation phase of an EI lesson, the teacher, through the task analysis, gives learners a clear set of steps to follow. During the modeling and practice phases of instruction, the continued use and reinforcement of these steps help learners to internalize the steps. This internalization assists learners to ultimately ‘own’ the critical skill being taught.

Once they have mastered the skill or strategy, they can then apply it in new situations and combine it with other skills to solve more complex problems. These are behaviors displayed by self-regulated learners.

Consider the EI Lesson Plan list below.
At what point would you conduct the task analysis? Why?

 

Explicit Instruction Lesson Plan:

  1. Lesson Introduction
  2. Teacher Explanation and Demonstration/Modeling
  3. Practice
  4. Closure

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Explicit Instruction and Task Analysis - Review and Planning Activity
page.contents:
In this lesson we examined a process for completing a task analysis of both a basic skill (adding decimals) and a higher order thinking strategy (reading comprehension – answering both literal and inferential questions). Remember:
A basic skill is a procedure that with practice can be performed automatically. Basic skills require very little or no higher order thinking.
A strategy is a procedure a learner uses to perform a complex task. Strategies are comprised of thinking and action steps to help learners develop higher order thinking skills.
 
As indicated, the task analysis forms the basis for the Explain and Model steps of the EI Lesson, as well as informing the prerequisite component of the Lesson Introduction. Thus the task analysis is a critical step in planning an EI lesson for either a skill or a strategy.

Consider the Lesson Introduction you designed for the assignment in Session 2. Was the focus of the lesson a skill or a strategy? If a skill, begin to think about how you would break this skill down into steps. If a strategy, consider how you would locate a tested procedure for this complex task.

You will be asked to conduct a task analysis as a part of the Assignment for Session #3.

Next we will examine how to conduct the Explain and Demonstrate/Model component of the EI Lesson plan format we are using.

Click Finish to end this lesson, return to the Main Course Menu, and access the next session section.
